description:
This is such a great neighborhood spot for sushi. As someone who lives in the area I come here on a regular basis (like once a month at least). The sushi itself is on point, fish is of good good quality. We ordered the sake don and it was delicious. The owners are super friendly. And the happy hour worth checking out. 

Look, this is not a fancy sushi place, I wouldn't travel a long way to eat here. For an unpretentious, local, family owned sushi restaurant, Sushi Rapture is "As good as it gets!".
author: Han C.

description:
Worth it for the Happy Hour deals! Oysters were good - I recommend using he sauce to get rid of the fishy smell 

Some rolls are better than others - I expect the ones with sauces taste better than ones topped with just sashimi

The sashimi is decent, although I have been to other places with fresher fish
author: Angela I.

description: Fantastic sushi hole in the wall. I have been coming for years and it remains one of my favorite restaurants in SF. Reliably good sushi and nice people.
author: Alex C.

description:
This place was great to me when I came in to read and eat. I wasn't feeling well so I ordered rice, miso soup, and wakame (seaweed salad). The cucumbers on the salad were really fragrant and everything I ate was really good. I've also come here in the past for their happy hours, oysters and sushi. 
Tips 
- $6/ 6 oysters on Tuesday
- Its really casual and some days it can get a bit loud
author: Gina B.

description:
Small cozy sushi spot that's been in the neighborhood for a while now. It's nothing fancy but you can definitely catch some colorful conversation at the bar between the family that runs the place.  

Happy hour Tuesday - Friday from 4-7pm but it's nothing much to get excited about. $3 hand-rolls lime spicy tuna, salmon, or crab but I think they shrink them at happy hour. Chicken karaage is decent but the toragashi that they sprinkle on it is a little tart. I think you're probably better off ordering from the regular menu because happy hour portions are tiny.

Sushi Rapture is a decent spot. Not the best Japanese food in the city but will suffice if you're looking to support a family-run business.
author: Jon L.

description:
Love this place. Really surprised they do not have four stars - for an out of the way neighborhood sushi place, the quality and presentation is outstanding. I learned about this place from KQED's Check Please: http://bit.ly/2nmV2zZ (go to 18:05 for the Sushi Rapture segment).

Everything seems super fresh. The first time we just told chef Sam (great guy!) to just hook us up à la omakase. We started off with the breaded fried scallops - perfectly breaded and crispy, and moist inside. Then Sam brought us a sashimi sampler - hotate (scallops) were a standout, like butter!

Subsequent visits we shared a lot of things - this time beef tataki with ponzu sauce, hoisin beef riblets, and a few of the rolls. All wonderful, with the hamachi toro and hotate (scallops) most outstanding. Again, this place serves it fresh.

Bento boxes for lunch are good, but I felt a little pricey - BUT, I do recall leaving with leftovers, so I guess I cannot complain.

So, a great place. Great staff and service.
author: Corey M.

description:
My dad took me here and he loved it his first time.  I couldn't get past the smell of urine in the restaurant.  Yes, I said it.  It smelled like the New York City subway.  Ordered a spicy tuna roll and that's it.  I'm a foodie,  I'll admit.  But how can anyone eat somewhere that smells like piss?

Had the spicy tuna roll, 5 bucks on Fridays.  It was ok.  But I'm a foodie and I will NOT be back.
author: Laurie S.

description:
Been meaning to post this for a couple months. The food isn't bad here. The service is good and attentive as well, however, Please double check your bill once you receive your credit card printed receipt. Twice this year, I was overcharged $10 - $14 once the original, itemized bill was taken and not returned with the credit card. Additionally, they don't print 2 receipts, one for your records. Shady!

The 1st time it happened, I thought maybe I was mistaken. Another visit proved me wrong and they claimed they printed the credit card receipt from a different table by accident. 

Nice, cozy neighborhood restaurant, but I won't be returning since they purposefully rip customers off by jacking up the bill when you pay by credit card. Either don't go or review your itemized bill carefully, then pay in cash.
author: Aaa T.

description:
I don't see how this place deserves a good review. We ordered a couple of items to go and it was almost $48.00...gee

1. chicken teriyaki noodle soup - any normal restaurant would separate the soup from the ramen to prevent the noodle from being too soggy. well, they didn't and by the time i got home, the noodle was not right and the chicken lost its flavor. most importantly, the broth was thin with no flavor. i suppose they did not know a good broth is the key of a great noodle soup. this dish did not meet expectations.

2. gyoza - they were very small and lacked flavor. i could have gotten the ling ling potstickers from costco and call it a day.

3. bento box with teriyaki chicken, salmon and tuna sashimi - they used your typical square clear plastic container which was so wrong. if they call it a bento box, for heaven's sake use something that remotely looks like a bento box. the quality of both sashimi were below average, let alone small. above all, it was way overpriced for what we got.

there are plenty of sushi place in town with better food and better prices. we certainly will not return for what they have to offer.
author: JC I.

description:
Having recently moved to Sushi Rapture's neighborhood, I've been eating here every chance I get. This hidden gem is only about 5 tables, but seem to have a bustling takeout scene. It is quaint, feels cozy and local, and has a killer happy hour!

New favorite roll: 49er with cooked shrimp
author: Kerry G.

description:
My friend suggested this spot after our yoga sesh nearby. I promptly looked it up on Yelp (out of habit)- only 3.5 stars? I normally wouldn't eat anywhere with a less than 4 star rating, because life is too short to eat shitty food, but desperate times call for desperate measures. We were all famished, and 7:30 is two hours past when my usual dinner time is. Unfortch, we missed their happy hour by 30 minutes. Would've been nice to get $1 oysters.

The restaurant is tiny and the seating is arranged so compactly. I couldn't figure out where to put my yoga mat for it to not be in the way of others. I ordered the unagi don and subbed the miso soup for seaweed salad for a $4 charge. It seems like they arbitrarily assigned this cost when I asked for the substitution, but I love seaweed and would've been willing to pay full price for it anyway. It came out with cucumbers arranged around the dish, which is super weird. I hate cucumbers, so I gave them to my friends. 

Our server tried to serve me a chicken teriyaki bowl, which is when I realized that he put in the wrong order. He didn't admit his mistake, but I knew from the nervous look on his face that he knew he'd messed up. I made it a point to show my displeasure because I was HANGRY. Every time he walked by, I would stare him down. My friends got their food and finished every last bite. 35 minutes later, I finally got my unagi rice bowl. The manager/owner (?) apologized for the delay, but by this point I was like whatever, just leave me be to stuff my face. You really can't go wrong with unagi; it's just inherently delicious, but it's unreasonably marked up. A bowl of rice and eel for $16? 

Our server offered each of us a scoop of green tea ice cream as penance for the long wait, and of course we accepted. There was also an adorable pup chilling at the table next to me, so the meal ended on a high note despite the mishap.
author: Karen S.

description: Thoroughly mediocre sushi restaurant. Has about 6 tables and a typical menu. The bathroom is in the kitchen which did not appear to be well maintained. Would consider this overpriced for a standard sushi restaurant.
author: Lauren B.

description:
i came here for dinner with my boyfriend and we ordered tempura, unagi don, and a bento box with 3 items. the tempura was good, but it was pretty overpriced for the portion size. i think there were 5 items for $9. half of my donburi was salad and the rest were rice and unagi, which didn't look like much. the unagi was delicious, but the donburi wasn't worth $17. the bento box was pretty pricey too for the portion size, around $19. if it weren't for the tempura, i don't think we would've been full with just one meal. i'd probably look elsewhere for cheaper japanese restaurants in nob hill.

some notes: the service was good, the waiter was pretty attentive. the restaurant is super tiny, not recommended for large groups. there's a small bar for people to sit. there's no ventilation, so it gets really stuffy inside the restaurant.
author: Sylvia H.

description: This place is really unique and even though the servers are a bit self absorbed  the food is amazing has great presentation and worth dealing with such self absorb people
author: Crystal M.

description: Ordered through Eat24. Pretty overpriced for what you get, and on top of that, every roll showed up with rotten avocado inside. Totally ruined my appetite.
author: Sarah R.

description:
Don't go for the happy hour. Oddly enough, the happy hour rolls aren't very good and frankly (I never thought I'd say this) but they didn't come with enough rice! In order to feel decently satisfied, you'd probably want to eat about five of them...

Which nicely leads to my next point. If you're going to order five happy hour specials then just skip to the chase and get a hand roll.

I ordered the salmon belly nigiri and boy was that heaven in my mouth  it was a little pricey ($7) but at least it tasted great!
author: Jennifer C.

description: This is my favorite local sushi spot! The service is great and the sushi melts in my mouth. My second photo only shows a portion of our roles because I needed to eat it before anything. Always ask for the specials, they always have something to make your mouth water. I had the Salmon Belly nigiri, snake roll and eclipse nigiri. To warm our belly's we also had agadashi tofu!
author: Katrina V.

description: Got this delivery through Eat24. Terrible. Fish was dry and tasted old. Couldn't even drown it in soy sauce to make it better. Even the wasabi was weird. I never leave yelp reviews but this basically ruined my night so here I am. Got the 49er roll and the yellow fin sashimi.
author: Russell H.

description: Gross! When you order shiro maguro and it comes to you stiff and practically frozen, tastes like that metallic fishy taste you DO NOT want, then you have a problem. I asked for some rolls without rice, and there was no creativity at all with it. Sad to say, I wont be ordering from sushi rapture again. The miso soup was decent.
author: Jasmine M.

description:
SO EXPENSIVE NOW!!
I ordered from delivery.com tonight, $33 total for a tekka don, saba shioyaki and gyoza. The order got canceled after 10 minutes. So we call to order on the phone for pickup.
I get to the restaurant, total of $46! I ask why the difference? The owner tells me that it is because delivery.com has a 6 years old menu.
Then I just checked my last 2 orders from Feb 2017 and Nov 2016. For everything that I ordered on these 2 orders, they raised prices between 25% and 40%, wow!!
I don't think they got the memo but we're not a the peak of San Francisco cost of life craziness, rents are going down and startups don't hire like crazy anymore.
We won't order from Sushi Rapture anymore, too much is too much.
author: Guillaume C.

description: I would give this place zero stars if I could. Horribly quality sushi that left a bad taste in my boyfriend and I's mouth for literally days after. Fish is of the lowest quality, and by that I mean you're chewing on the raw fish for longer than comfortable to break up the stringy texture. It doesn't help that it has that old, frozen, fishy flavor that lingers in your mouth. The rolls were over flavored with sauces, probably to mask the fish flavor but to no avail. And to top it off, it's not cheap either. Sorry for being graphic but this establishment is an embarrassment to sushi and I would discourage any one from going here.
author: Christine D.

description:
Sushi Rapture's happy hour is what I would call a SCREAMING deal. It's probably one of the best deals I've found in city yet, both in terms of price and options. It's a great neighborhood spot (we've been living in the area for years, and have heard so many great things from friends/neighbors), where the regulars are greeted by name by the staff. Their happy hour menu is rather generous and we basically ordered every item on the menu. The $1 oysters (only on Tuesdays) was by far the best deal, along with the $1 miso soup, $2 edamame, $2 hand rolls, and $2 beer. Seriously though, what more do you need?? The oysters were fantastic (super creamy), wonderful miso and edamame (better than at most places), and generously sized hand rolls (for the price). 

Service was fast and friendly, and they were taking happy hour orders until the very last minute. We also ordered the 49er roll, the creamy roll, the bluefin tuna special, tomago nigiri, and uni. The 49er roll was one of the best rolls I've ever had (no exaggeration), but the creamy roll was really hard to eat (the pieces fell apart as soon as you picked them up). The fish tasted incredibly fresh, and we left feeling very full and satisfied. 

My only complaint (and the reason for a 4/5 star review) is the space constraints. The restaurant is incredibly small, and they have far too many tables crammed inside. Perhaps if the tables were smaller it would be easier, but we were practically sitting on top of the people around us. The diners next to us actually had to pull the table from the wall to get out of their seats. Beyond the cramped space, which is probably due to their awesome happy hour, I would highly recommend this spot. Fresh, reliable sushi and great happy hour prices!
author: Regina L.

description:
Went there yesterday for the first time during their Happy Hour, which was 4pm-7pm ($2 Asahi, Kirin, Sapporo )
I had the Miso, absolutely delicious and I knew right then that it would be a good experience. I ordered the Shrimp Tempura and vegetables, which was good.
I had the Snake Roll, which had spicy tuna, cilantro, and salmon, It was fresh and the combination with the cilantro is one I'm going to ask for again. I also had the 49er roll which had scallop, salmon and lemon, and was also very good. The food was very fresh and delicious and they did not skimp on the fish. I will definitely be going back.
author: Patricia S.

description: My husband and I eat sushi every week, no matter where we are. We were in San Fran, found Sushi Rapture and so glad we did!! The place is small but packs a big punch! I emailed for reservations, I received a conformation within in minutes. The staff was friendly, the chiefs so accommodating and the fish, so fresh!! I wish we lived closer!!! This would be our local go to place. Tip: try the Pumpkin, an upbeat sashimi/nigiri: spicy scallops wrapped in a generous piece of fresh salmon with just a touch of rice to off set the heat. It was amazing!! Truly a signature item.
author: L A.

description: Ordered from here a couple of times because of proximity. Small portions and mediocre quality for a pretty exorbitant price - 6 pieces in a roll for 13$+? Pictures from the menu are not at all accurate to what's served and several times I was charged a different amount than was advertised on the menu. Won't be returning.
author: Riley C.

description: Some different but very tasty sushi rolls! My only issue, and of course we went during a record breaking heatwave, was that it was a bit "stuffy" there is no AC and is a pretty small dinging room. I myself do not enjoy sweating while I eat however the ice cold Sapporo helped. I will definitely be back here for 49ers Roll and Lindsay roll! Both of those were YUMMMMYYYY!!!
author: Rosie S.

description: We got sushi delivered to our hotel. Service and delivery was friendly enough and our order arrived during the promised time.  My daughter really liked the edamame and gave her sushi roll 3 stars. She ordered a rainbow roll with all salmon and soy paper. I ordered the spider roll cut roll and it was okay. I also ordered the salmon belly sushi with garlic and it too was just okay.
author: Cheyenne P.

description: Great little neighborhood spot. Popped in on a cold rainy night. Fast and Friendly service. 4PM-7PM Tuesday - Friday Russian Hill Happy Hour Specials include:2 for 1 Drink Special: Sake. $1 Oysters. $2 Sushi hand rolls. $2 edamame. $1 Miso Soup. $2 Beer. Will be back again!
author: Belle S.

description:
Really bad service. I've tried during all different service times and disappointed each time. People working there are too busy with "order out" requests that the the service within suffers. 

I'd rather try different local sushi places then give them another shot. Bummed out bc I love so close.
author: Blythe B.

description: Very good neighborhood sushi. Check out the happy hour specials on weeknights. Servers were friendly and restaurant was busy with local patrons.
author: Emily G.

description:
Uninspiring sushi in this otherwise great neighborhood.

The $8.95 lunch special (12pm-3pm) comes with the standard miso soup and salad.

I'm so uninspired writing a review, I should've just written a quick tip.
author: Janice C.

description:
A rather weird name for a Sushi spot but since the neighborhood is not blessed with too many options I gladly went in here for lunch time.

The lunch special (miso, salad, rice, and two items) sounded like a good value ($8.95) and it turned out to be just okay. Don't expect an overfloating bento box, instead, the teriyaki beef was put sparely into one corner, while I had to look closely to discover the chicken katsu. I was telling myself that for $8.95 I can't expect much but still, a bit disappointing the portion size.

Taste-wise, I've seen much better Japanese food but let's be generous and stick with 3 stars. 

The spot is really small and more a corner/neighborhood restaurant - reservations not needed. Walk up the hill and forget about parking - you're in Nob HILL.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
Ordered for delivery through Yelp/Eat24 and were disappointed. It was below expectations, and worse than supermarket sushi. Not a good value, and we were not able to finish it. It was fishy and not fresh.

Would not order again.
author: Tomás G.

description: Been looking for a satisfying sushi place for awhile now. New to the city and sushi rapture is exactly what you want out of a sushi spot. Cute place and the fish was extremely fresh, cold, and presentable. Got the yellowtail nigiri and it melted in my mouth. Would highly recommend. Good service too nice people
author: Courtney M.

description: If you are looking for fancy rolls, not the spot.  If you are looking for nigiri or sashimi, this place kills it.  The fish is great, the Saki is not.  It is very unassuming and unpretentious which I love.  It's also right next to where I live and on a quite street which is nice also.
author: Dan J.

description: I'm conflicted about this place. On one hand, I really love their sushi. It's definitely the best quality in my neighborhood, always fresh and tasty. Their Pumpkin Nigiri is to die for. On the other hand, their customer service is a bit eccentric and sometimes it feels like they don't really want customers there. But I'm a sucker for their sushi, so I keep going there.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Decent sushi restaurant - good for pick up!
Their salmon sashimi is on point... others not as good.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Love this place, been coming for 10 Years. TV, nice, warm dining room and experience, awesome staff, and locals you'll see all the time.

I like to have them make Eel + creamcheese roll.
author: Heber S.

description: The five stars are solely for their salmon belly sushi special. It is the best sushi I have had in San Francisco. The salmon belly was very fatty and smooth. It is also thicker than most other SF restaurants would make it. Reminds me of sushi I've had in Hong Kong. Other things on the menu are nothing spectacular.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Ordered delivery. 

We picked chicken karaage, sushi combo, an extra albacore maki, ikura nigiri, two miso soups, and fried banana with green tea ice cream.

First thing first, we were missing both the albacore maki and the ikura nigiri we ordered.

On the ones we did get, had hard pieces of unseasoned rice. The karaage was stale.

Doesn't come with utensils, so be careful If you order anything that can't be eaten with your hands!

Never again.
author: Peter W.

description:
How you gonna call a place SUSHI RAPTURE and not give me a rapturous experience?! To be fair, the food was edible and okay, but I could've gotten something better from Nijiya's deli. It was okay food, but far from rapturous. Sigh.

Ordered this for delivery and it came on time, which was good.

Tiny portions, fish was meh, rice had no flavor and was kind of hard. It's cool that they have a lot of options, but for the price, it was overpriced more than anything else. Plus, the rolls were generally tasteless. That should not happen with scallops, because scallops are delicious, and this was just meh. There are better sushi places out there. This was all right, but nothing special.
author: Robbin A.

description: Wanted to love this place since it's the closest restaurant to our apartment but probably the worst ramen I've ever eaten. Only redeeming factors are the friendly service and decent sushi.
author: Daniel S.

description: The fish of the Sushi (California and Rainbow roll) was not fresh, my husband asked a BBQ Short Ribs Soup and it was more noodles than meat. We buy it to pick it up and eat at home but definitely it's not a good idea.
author: Erika V.

description:
Found a disgusting LONG PIECE OF HAIR in my Oyako Don.

This screams unsanitary as hell, and I lost my appetite completely.

The chicken in the Oyako Don was also clumpy - like they just dumped clumps of frozen chicken and heated it up. There was little to no flavor at all. Peas and mushrooms seemed like random additions to "fluff" up the dish - never had such unauthentic Oyako Don. Then while picking at the food, I found the piece of hair. 

*GAG*

I also had a couple of standard sushi rolls, but after finding the hair, I kept thinking how unsanitary the raw fish may be. 

Yes, I'm basing this review on just this one dish, but I don't care how good the other dishes may be - finding the hair in just one dish is enough to represent the quality of this restaurant's standards and the food that comes with it.
author: Vickie Z.

description:
first of all they served me cold edamame, that was probably refrigerated the whole night before. 
they just care about making money, not the food quality.
author: Billie E.

description: Very good food and awesome pricing. Money well spent . Will definetly recommend people to come here. My favorite is the hand rolls. And service here is awesome too. Do come by!
author: Jimmy S.

description: Great sushi place in a great neighborhood. Something about this place that makes it stand out from other sushi places. Prices are reasonable.
author: Edward C.

description:
The worst customer service I have every experienced in my life- Because it had been over 20 minutes since I'd ordered and no one had been by to deliver food, I asked the server how long it would take. She got very angry for some reason and started arguing with me- I told her I wasn't interested in arguing with her and I just wanted to know if it would take longer than another 5 minutes, because I was on a time limit and needed to go. She continued to argue with me, was incredibly rude and said that I should go elsewhere if I wanted. So I told her I would, and I left. I've been here on a few other occasions and the service is always terrible- The sushi sub par. Lose lose situation if you ask me. It's a block from my apartment, so I decided to give it one more go. The same lady, after taking my order, came back and asked me "Aren't you the person who left a few months ago?" I said "yes, and I told you I was leaving after you started attacking me." She proceeded to AGAIN start arguing with me. I told her I was not interested in arguing with her and that's why I left in the first place. She told me that they wouldn't take my order. I'm completely appalled that anyone like this can continue to be in business- It's ridiculous that people like this even exist!

Avoid at all costs and opt for Elephant Sushi down the street.
author: Rashmi J.

description: Blue Fin, yellow fin, solid every time. Scallop sashimi in a sauce topped with shaved green-onion-which was a special, AMAZING. Also incredibly tasty for a non-raw meal, tepan sea bass. The broth-like sauce the bamboo shoots and and fish are sizzling in is brown and very tasty. Great food with very warm company from San at sushi bar. Come often. :)
author: Barbie B.

description: Cool little sushi restaurant in Nob Hill. I came here for happy hour that is Tuesday-Friday, 4-7pm. Beers are $2 and so are the hand rolls. The salmon hand roll was my favorite, really fresh fish. My only thought is that they were on the small side. I had 3 of them which left me hungry. But they're $2 each so it's a good value and I can always order more.
author: Jared B.

description: Go-to neighborhood sushi spot. Fish is good and the restaurant is clean. I've ordered delivery from here a few times as I live down the street and it has been good so far.
author: Amanda S.

description: As everyone else has mentioned, the happy hour is a good deal. But only for drinks. I don't recommend the fish unless you're someone who just loves rolls. In that case, I'm sure you'd find some great fatty fish rolls. The crowd pleasers are in full form. You can get salmon belly and tuna belly but don't expect any of the good stuff for happy hour. Get there for happy hour but I can't think of any other reason to stay
author: Chinthrilla M.

description: Home made soup was delicious. Location is great. They also have happy hours from tuesday to friday so might pop in these days. No music though. And the environment is nothing special.
author: Veronika J.

description: Sushi Rapture is on a quiet street with the occasional cable car going.by. The Owner Sam is a happy  fun host. He selects the fish fresh every day.  We had an expert at our table " Ivy " who ordered for us. wow. what great food.  U have to try this..5 Stars!!!
author: David C.

description: Perfect chefs suggestion butterfish and hamachi, soft shell card and teriyaki chicken for Valerie
author: Geanr L.

description:
Had a takeout sushi night while holed up at our AirBnB crib a couple blocks away. Not the very best maki I've ever had, but certainly quite good. Comes down to -- how much more time do you want to spend hunting up something possibly, maybe a little better?

Deliberately went a little Bay Area homage crazy with a Raider roll (Halibut, White Tuna), 49er roll (Scallop, Salmon, Lemon) and a Giants roll (Spicy Hamachi and Salmon) -- must have hit on a good night as all were quite fresh tasting and with interesting contrasts between the rolls.

Also helped that the edamame was not overcooked or over-salted. Yay!

Prices were merely OK, but on the upside our order was ready in about 20 minutes. Walking up to the very small corner space we'd passed many times during the week it was clear that -- for us -- take out was the way to go on this night of big hunger and a short window. Like many sushi ops staffing seemed iffy, with one guy trying to both greet take-out orders and wrangle cold beers from the cooler. You admire the want-to and the smiles amid the chaos, but you know something could go sideways. 

No matter.

If you believe in imperfect, neighborhood joints you'll hit up Sushi Rapture for take out or for a more leisurely sit-down meal. It won't be perfect -- just very, very good.
author: Jeff T.

description:
I came here with two of my friends last Sunday evening. We were quickly seated in the tiny space, and we ordered the following:
1) SPIDER RAINOW ROLL: 
2) SWAMP ROLL: Which I loved, but that's because I have a strange affinity to seaweed salad.
3) SNAKE ROLL: Which was pretty good (despite the fact that I'm not a huge fan of cilantro -- but my friend ordered it, so we got that).
4) (SOME SORT OF NOODLE DISH): I really can't remember what my friend got. She was indifferent about it).
5) BREADED SCALLOPS: Um. Okay -- so here's a story.

We ordered the BREADED scallops. We even pointed to the front, which was an appetizer. For some reason, we got a miso soup and salad with the breaded scallops (appetizer) -- but we were like, "maybe it's just really good service". Then we get teh scallops, super duper huge. Again, we just thought it was the restaurant.

Once we get the bill, we realized that they had charged us for the DEEP-FRIED scallops -- an entrée, which was $10 more. We tell them that they made a huge mistake. We ask if they can reduce the payment to $8 (which was how much it originally cost), and we'll just give them a bigger tip. They go back to ask, and tell us scallops are really expensive (which I understand), and said that they would give us a $2 discount. REALLY? A $2 DISCOUNT, when it was YOUR fault? Then we ask again if they can change it, since really - we had explicitly said breaded scallops. They come back out and said that they would give us a $5 discount and free ice cream (however, my friends didn't want ice cream). So in the end, the waiter that took our order had absorbed the cost of the scallops in total.

I felt bad for the guy. However, it was a pretty big mistake on his end (or whoever's end). We were pretty upset. The sushi was meh. I think I would just get delivery from them, but don't think I would ever go there to grab food at the restaurant again.
author: Joanne W.

description: I love this place. Super fresh fish and the nicest people work there.  I would recommend that you ask the chef to get creative, and you will not be disappointed. He obviously loves the art of sushi, and will present dishes with special ingredients  that you don't normally see in your average joint, or other little items that you might see in waayyyy more expensive places.  It's a small place, so the details are in the freshness of the fish, the friendly and knowledgeable staff, and feeling that you will try something yummy.  Also... and just as important, the basics like miso soup, gyoza, and larger rolls are all excellent.  If you can, try for the happy hour and/or $1. oysters!
author: Selena M H.

description:
So while running around San Fran on a recent pleasure excursion, I found myself wanting lunch deep in the "hills" and after a quick search on my Yelp App found Sushi Rapture.

Centrally located, this tiny little place must be a god-send for this neighborhood as there isn't much else in the way of eateries for blocks.  The folks inside are nice and a cute little seat by the window allows one to watch the day-to-day San Francisco pass you by.

I order a few basic rolls and a beer and relaxed for a moment during my trip. The rolls were good, though nothing to rave about and the pricing was average.

All and all a nice little place for a nice little meal.
author: Michael E.

description: our son just moved to nob hill and in anticipation of our visit, I looked up several different sushi bars on yelp.  was concerned as lots of yelp chatter about long lines, noisy, rude or inattentive service as well as paper thin fish.  sushi rapture--my sons secret locals spot was awesome.  no wait on a fri night at 7pm for 3 at sushi bar.  perfect friendly service as well as amazing nigiri --melts in the mouth and very large pieces for $5.95.  kirin rainbow roll also excellent.  we will have to visit our son more often just for the sushi!!!!
author: Bill T.

description:
Sushi Rapture is the kind of cool neighborhood place to go.  No tourists.   I tell friends about it
if I think they're sufficiently hip to appreciate it.
author: Norman R.

description:
Fresh sashimi beautifully cut. 
Excellent beef tataki. Tasty gyoza. Adventurous nigiri (try the "pumpkin"). If they offer a halibut special - take it!
The only downer - the bottles of Asahi were warm.
author: Paul S.

description: Ordered chirashi through door dash. No utensils, fish portions were tiny (I just got little tidbits of fish instead of proper slices). Rice wasn't seasoned really, tasted more like just plain cold rice. Ginger was also spread out all over the rice, which as weird. For the price, this wasn't worth it.
author: Rhea K.

description:
probably / surprisingly my favourite sushi place in san Francisco so far.  I kind of assumed it'd be bad because it's in a residential area (and places like that can kind of get away with tasting like shit out of convenience).

butt it was great.  people who work there are really laid back and young.  happy hour is phenomenal.  $2 hand rolls that are fillllled with sashimi?  so down.  the sushi rolls are also the biggest I've seen in san Francisco so far, esp for the price.

in the neighborhood,
if you like sushi, come to sushi rapture.
if you like Americanized sushi, go to elephant sushi.
if you don't like sushi, go to sushi rock.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
just ordered from this place for ubereats. everything that was supposed to be hot was cold..perhaps its uber's fault and not this place. 

However! from 2 rolls and a saba bento..I ate three pieces of plastic. One in the roll, one in the saba...and just when I thought I was safe with the lukewarm miso soup. bam! piece of plastic. how does that happen??
author: Vivian L.

description:
I ordered delivery since I was craving Japanese food and it was a mixed review:

The New York Steak was RAW. I said I want it MEDIUM. It was bloody raw. The meat quality was good but it was RAW.

The beef teriyaki was good. They used old quality meat.

The Chicken Karaage was good but it wasn't crunchy
author: Leslie M.

description: Love Sushi Rapture. I visited for my boyfriend's birthday a couple of weeks ago and we had a great time. Cute little neighborhood sushi joint--and the service was fantastic. Love this place! Keep being awesome.
author: Victoria S.

description: This place is good but have had a couple less than stellar experiences.  The sushi generally is a bit warmer than I like (sometimes above room temp, which is off putting).  Not sure why that is.  They have good deals on drinks and specials which have brought me back.  Usually I stick to rolls here and can't really go wrong.
author: Paul L.

description: Sushi Rapture's tonkatsu is one of the best I've tasted! PLUS, the
author: Bernadeth Regine A.

description:
EAT24 delivered the food - the condiments were not with the order.  
Food was Good - Seafood Soup (should have had more seafood), Gyoza Chicken - Good, Not Greasy and Nicely Cooked - Green Tea Ice Cream (not enough in one serving) - The Sashimi Combo  - Good, Fresh, Good Price - I will call this restaurant again.
author: Andrrs B.

description: Most disgusting chicken katsu I've ever SEEN. I had one bite and it tasted as awful as it looked. When it arrived it was cold and it was not worth the wait. I called and they're sending me sushi instead though so that's cool. I hope they don't spit in it...
author: Chessie C.

description:
I had dinner with a friend last night at sushi rapture. We arrived around 7:30 to a completely empty restaurant but it did seem to start filling up around 8:30. They also did a lot of take out orders while we were there so maybe that's their bread and butter. Looks like they also deliver. The restaurant is small but they could accommodate a larger group by pushing tables together - but definitely call ahead if your party is more than 4 people.

They have a very large menu including hot items, but given the beautiful weather, we went straight for the sushi rolls. We ordered a spicy tuna roll, giants roll, raider roll and 49 roll. I guess we were in a sports mood? Everything was delicious and we were stuffed after that. We probably could have ordered just 3 and been fine. We also split a small bottle of sake which was yummy.

Service was generally good and it was not horrifically expensive for the amount of food we got. Would definitely return!
author: Rachel E.

description: Kudos to the courier who picks up the last remaining sushi items from Safeway and Whole Foods, then gets them to Sushi Rapture in time to be repackaged and sold 2 days later. This is what low-end bait tastes like.
author: Yowz A.

description:
Asked for a deep fried California Roll. The price difference between a Non-fried California Roll and a Fried one? $6.50 vs. $10.50 just to stick it in the deep fryer. 

The pieces were SO big I could not eat them in one bite. Had to messily eat half a piece at a time with seaweed hanging out of my mouth and rice dribbling down my chin (trust me, it was not a cute site). Mostly filled with the imitation crab, hardly any avocado in it. 

Service was good though.
author: Rupa A.

description: Been here a few times and have always been pleased. I recommend coming on a Tuesday and/or for happy hour.  $1 oysters are a must on Tuesdays! Service has always been consistently good, not great but good, no complaints. They have off menu specials that are always fun to try and do not disappoint. The beef tataki is recommended, it tantalizes the taste buds and always aims to please  It's a small place but it's not about the size ... Anyway, come here and try for yourself.
author: Jason C.

description: Great neighborhood sushi bar. The owners were super friendly and knew their repeat customers by name. They also made suggestions based on the fish they just received from Japan that day. I will definitely be back!
author: Elaine Tiffany P.

description:
Decent sushi place! I wish I had the option of giving a 3.5-star instead of just a 3-star. :(

I believe this place is family-owned and they're definitely a lively bunch! I love chatting with the Chefs come closing time as they have some pretty hilarious stories to tell! Sushi and menu items are okay, but nothing spectacular or very memorable. Pretty basic items--which isn't a bad thing--but if you're looking for the WOW factor in a sushi place, there are definitely other sushi places around the city that can do the trick.
author: Rachel C.

description:
Go-to sushi in Nob Hill, and probably the best sushi happy hour in San Francisco. Happy hour: 2 dollar handrolls, 1 dollar oysters, 2 for 1 sake. 

Other great finds on the menu: shiro snake (yellowtail, avacado and cilantro) and the lineup of quail egg nigiri. 

Sam and Andrea are fantastic proprietors, and the price is tough to complain about. It's not mindblowingly great, but it's still pretty darn good.
author: Sean F.

description:
FOOD:
Rolls =  normal
Happy hr on oysters


SERVICE
Fine. One time they were completely busy, and made us wait even though I could see it would be a longer wait than 15 minutes. Hangry girls here. And a handful of other sushi spots on Polk to go to.


ATMOSPHERE
Basic, small.

11.2.13
author: Angela L.

description:
Delivery order was hot and fairly quick.  Beef and egg noodle soup was rather plain. Good flavor, but beef was fatty and not many vegetables in it. 
But delivery was free, so I'll probably order again, but try something different.
author: Carolyn C.

description:
Just your average non-Japanese sushi restaurant. Service was good, but the food was just lacking. I've had better sushi from Nijiya Market. Fish quality wasn't great, and their rolls were lacking inspiration.

I mean... if you're going to be like every other Americanized sushi restaurant, at least make some interesting rolls that taste great, ya know?
author: Kazu O.

description:
I was out for a walk in the neighborhood and saw this place was packed, so I decided it was worth a chance.

Vegetarians such as myself can't really write the most accurate review of a sushi bar, but I can still report that the prices and presentation were darling for the neighborhood.

Atmosphere: Close-quarters, but done in a cute and social manner

Crowd: Nob Hillians, Marina district thirty-somethings, dates
 
Cost: A little steep, but happy hour is spot on

Try: Tuesdays (between 4 and 7), buy one get one free sake, cheap hand rolls, etc.

Skip: Basic maki, the specialty maki are much more substantial for the price
author: Taylor S.

description: Very hip atmosphere, family style Japanese restaurant. Small place with nice staffs and great food. Always ask the servers for specials of the day, They will surprise you.
author: Yan C.

description:
Chirashi don + miso soup for $14.95?  Yes!

Perfectly seasoned rice.
Fresh fish overall.  

Usually my favorite sashimi is salmon.  (I'm a simple person.)  However, I was surprised to find that this was the least fresh tasting out of all the different pieces of fish I got.  (This is preventing this restaurant review from becoming a 5 star.)

The BUTTERFISH / escolar / "super white tuna" was actually the surprising win out of the selection.  This was definitely the FRESHEST that I have had in quite some time.

Also, I'm not sure if this is true all the time, but the night that I was there, the "Chef's Special" was essentially the same thing as the Chirashi Don, except that the rice came on the side.

The interior is pretty small.  There was a group of about 10 people sitting on one side, so if you call ahead, they can probably push the tables together.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
A lone beacon of Sushi amongst the apartments of Nob Hill, it's tiny, it's cool and the food is okay. There are about 6 tables and a few seats at the bar so even when its half-full, it feels busy. We were seated right away and the service was prompt and friendly.

I liked the Spicy Tuna Roll and the Caterpillar Roll was good but the tempura batter on the veggies was thick & gummy and the Sashimi slices were extremely tiny. I was also a little shocked at the prices for the roles but I guess you pay a bit more for convenience especially if you live around here.
author: G C.

description: Love that they are ok to deliver even if we're on the other side of the city - other sushi places much closer refuse to deliver to our building. And they always deliver on time and it's very tasty. I personally love the Cherry Blossom!
author: Doriane M.

description: My husband and I love this place.  It's truly a Nob Hill neighborhood gem - friendly service, consistently fresh and delicious sushi, and great happy hour specials.  I think the majority of the negative reviews are from people that have ordered takeout through third party services and I'm not sure that's a fair assessment.  Go check it out in person.  Grab a low key dinner there during happy hour and you won't be disappointed!
author: Riley D.

description: Pretty good sushi for the price. Cooked items like beef teriyaki and halibut teriyaki were fairly dry.
author: Chris A.

description:
New to Nob Hill and I've been looking for a good sushi place. We loved Sushi Rapture and will definitely be going back. 
They used real crab and no imitation stuff. That gets points in my book!
author: Joel D.

description: Absolutely delicious and fresh. Almost didn't come here because of the 3-star review, but glad we did -- huge, fresh cuts of fish, friendly chef & staff, and saw a few locals leaving who seemed like regulars. Don't miss out! Try this place.
author: Jana S.

description: Came here for lunch on a Sunday. They had a few sushi deals but nothing too crazy. Had a sampling of sushi, maki, and nigiri and it was all very fresh and tasty. The chef was also very friendly. I would definitely try this place again.
author: Kyle S.

description:
I love the location and quaintness of this place, and the tuna and salmon sashimi were delicious -- why 3 stars?  It was the smallest portion of sashimi I have ever eaten in my entire life.  I'm talking like 1 cm bites of sashimi.  I had to order 2 orders because I was still so hungry throughout the meal.

I don't get it -- just make the cut a little bigger, and bam, 4 stars.
author: Mel G.

description:
If you're looking for traditional sushi than look further. Much, much further. Sushi Rapture is just another roll factory in ritzy Nob Hill. Here is the lowdown:

The sushi counter is awkward. It's really, really tall. So tall you can barely see the sushi chef. So tall you might have to order from the waitress. There is garnish covering all the fish in the neta cases - which is really weird. The place gets roasting so they have to keep the front door propped open with a barstool. The window walls will ensure your back is on fire before you get your first piece of fish. 

The beer selection is limited - kirin, sapporo, and asahi. No tap. The rice was low grade, old, and squeezed far too hard under the nigiri. No gently falling apart or accent of wasabi under the fish. I could literally bounce the rice ball off my plate and the form was unmodified. The uni was from Santa Barbara, but wasn't sweet so it must have been low grade or old - I'm guessing this is due to the low demand. The ikura was old, foggy, and salty. The nori was chewy and old. They didn't carry real wasabi. 

There was a few good things. The chef was honest enough. The hamachi belly was fatty and good. As with the butterfish. 

All in all I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone who is serious about traditional sushi.
author: Grayson K.

description: This place is not good at all. I ordered the California Maki and the snake roll. The Cali roll had some gross flavor in the crab mixture, almost like a mayo to hold it together or something. Just not the flavor you want in that roll at all. The next roll I got was the snake roll. Unless you like to eat giant full leaves of cilantro DO NOT ORDER. This roll would be amazing without the cilantro because the fish in it was great. There was just soo much cilantro that you couldn't even taste the fish. Also like why cilantro? Use cucumbers and avocados instead. And The salmon on top of it was just too thick and a bit over powering. Maybe other things here are better but I definitely won't order from here again.
author: Lauren S.

description: I've given this place 4 chances since I live so close.  Disappoints every time.  Service slow, sushi mediocre.  Ordered take out halibut teriyaki and they forgot to put the teriyaki sauce on it,  I was the only customer in there as well and they still got this wrong.
author: Jay H.

description:
Great happy hour special. $2 hand rolls and beers. Cute place to stumble in on

Great service food was pretty good. Would com back again
author: John L.

description: Decided to try this place since it was very close to where I was. The inside of the restaurant is very small, maybe will fit about 30 people. I ordered the dinner bento box which consisted of Cali roll, tonkatsu and shrimp & vegetable tempura. Overall, the food was okay. For their Cali roll, they use fake crab (which I'm not a big fan of) and The tonkatsu didn't really have much flavor. The tempura was the same, I felt like I was just eating bread crumbs. As for parking, you might have to park a couple of blocks away.
author: Angela Z.

description: I ordered sushi rapture for delivery: salmon sashimi and some special nigiri. The nigiris were pretty good, but the salmon sashimi was below average. The pieces were very small and the quality of the fish not what I  expected. I won't order from there again.
author: Hadria W.

description:
In a city full of incredible food (and incredible sushi) you either need to have stellar sushi or affordable prices...this place has neither.  Sushi Rapture is less than 2 blocks from my house and I'll honestly never come again.  It's not bad sushi by any means but it isn't great either.  

I ordered a rainbow roll and a seaweed salad to go one night as I walked home and was sadly quite disappointed at what I got for just under $20.  The cuts of fish were small, the roll pretty standard.  The seaweed salad was TINY for the price.

I really do wish this place was better - I'd love to throw it in my rotation of takeout but its neither good or affordable.  Step it up Sushi Rapture.
author: Jessica J.

description:
Still looking for a substitute for Ebisu, but Sushi Rapture will have to do for now!

A few tables, but never a long wait. Service is a little slow sometimes, but they are working hard with a smile. 

The dragon/caterpillar roles are delicious! There seems to be a lot of returning customers who are familiar with the chef so thats a good sign.
author: Roll N.

description: Took away one time and it was quite disappointing. Nothing like a real Japanese place. Udon was like instant noodle, and sushi was just like some piece of fish over a rice ball. Maybe we will try one time to eat at the restaurant, hopefully only take away orders are mediocre.
author: Micha M.

description: We only visit SF a few times a year, and my wife is a sushi aficionado. She ordered to let the chef make her selections, and the sushi was fresh and generously portioned. Oysters were fine too. However, disappointment with my BBQ ribs: the beef was very tough. We'll go back for the sushi and hope the ribs were an anomaly.
author: Chris N.

description:
Quaint. 

Decently priced for being located in Nob Hill. 

Walked in and was immediately seated for lunch. Waitress was attentive and provided good service. 

Sushi was enjoyable.
author: Shawn O.

description: My go-to for quick, yummy sushi in my neighborhood. The sake sashimi and chicken teriyaki are always on point.
author: Roya S.

description: Delivery service sucks. 90 minutes for mediocre food??? No thank you.
author: Mike G.

description:
It is extremely difficult to get good sushi delivered. Seamless, Caviar--none of them have Blowfish, Ozumo or Sushi Groove delivery options. But they do have Sushi Rapture--and while it's the best of the ones I've tried (Naked Fish, Sushi Rock, so many more...), it's just ok.

Let's start with the good stuff--the prices are pretty reasonable. Not a deal per se, but a buck or two less expensive than many places. They also have a reasonably deep menu including sukiyaki and teriyaki.

But at the end of the day their nigiri and maki are just ok. The spider roll was loaded with lots of great crab, but their california roll was terrible, filled with pungent mock crab meat. The ebi tempura was way over fried and the maguro and uni were pretty bland.

I'm not going to hurt SR too much on this--but the delivery experience was bad. I'll mention this on Seamless too because they need to be aware of it. I tipped this guy $4 and he wouldn't even come to my apartment. He called me from his cell outside of my apartment and was like "uh, there's no parking, can you come down?" I was like "dude, I just tipped you four bucks and you won't deliver this to my door?"

He also forgot chopsticks which I intentionally called out on Seamless.
author: Paul C.

description: Love this sushi joint a lot. Excellent and fast customer service. Oysters, Ankimo, and uni teppan steak and sea bass are all MUST try items. Good selection of sashimi.
author: Aaron L.

description:
It's cute to see this sushi restaurant that stands by itself in a primarily residential area.  Parkimg is very tough, but I managed by parking in Polk Street three blocks away at 6pm just as metered parking spots becomes free. I got some exercise walking a few blocks uphill to this restaurant in the process.

For $14.95, I got the 16-piece sashimi combo (featuring tuna, salmon, yellowtail, and the white tuna that's truly white in color). It was quite tasty and fresh, albeit the slices were done in rather small pieces. The mackeral nigiri I got on the side was yummy also.

Here on weekdays before 7pm they have Happy Hour special featuring $2 for certain beer and hot sake, as well as certain handrolls.

Very nice service also, in particular I admired the one female server with the all black hair. :)
author: H K.

description: Decent sushi but priced way to high for the quality.  Better sushi places for the same price just up hyde street
author: Scott S.

description:
Stopped in with a group of four on recommendation from friend and fellow yelper, Nick S. I was pleasantly suprised to find this small Nob Hill sushi joint serving up some delightfully fresh choices! Not to mention the prices are so great for what you get.

I can certainly say they had some of the best presentation I've seen! Every roll was crafted with a bright balance of colors and flavors. Total art! Most impressive was the Pumpkin roll with it's spicy orange flair.

The Snake Roll was also uniquely tasty, combining spicy tuna and salmon with cilantro! I don't believe i've enjoyed cilantro in my sushi before. But something tells me my mexican/japanese husband would be in heaven!

Bonus points for the water being served in giant goblets. I felt like the queen of france.
author: Nikki M.

description: I can see why people keep this strictly take out. Sushi is okay. They add a cucumber in the CA rolls so it tastes really different from what you're used to eating. Uni is no good here. I'm not even looking for amazing sushi. I just want to satisfy the "I'm craving sushi so anything standard will do". This place kind of does that...and kind of doesn't.
author: Diana Y.

description: It's not that this place is horrible - its just not good. For example, the california rolls are worst than the pre-packaged grocery store/fake crab variety. And its overpriced. however, that also means its the only place in this neighborhood that doesn't have a line, hence the extra star. So, basically, its OK if you are desperate.
author: Tailor A.

description:
Great food, great people, great atmosphere!

I generally come here weekly because they are so awesome!

My favorite things to eat :
Snake Roll
Creamy Roll
Oysters
Breaded Scallops
Grilled Scallops
Grilled Sea Bass
Short Ribs

P.S. if you haven't had ONI SAKE yet. you may want to try some :]

Advice from a person who loves food (ME):
Seriously, this place is not for shy people, if you didn't get something or you are waiting...just ask them. Logical sense :] Speaking up will also help you meet super cool regulars that are in super cool professions.  

Toodles!
author: Dee N.

description:
Note to this establishment, restaurant ramen isn't supposed to taste like the ramen I cook at 3am and don't remember I ate the next morning. Wow the worst ramen I've had hands down. Just take it off the menu.
Our group also got a bunch of rolls and they were decent, but nothing to write home about. Except one roll (I believe the New York Maki roll) had so much cilantro that you may think it's a Mexican dish, which wasn't exactly pleasant.
It's a cute very small place with a nice staff, but I definitely won't be going out of my way to return.
author: Chris D.

description:
Um 2 for 1 large sakes on Tuesdays ... What else can I say?  

Okay, I guess I can say a bit more ...
On Tuesdays, it's also $1 oysters.  YUM.  
Snake roll is one of my favorites.  It's spicy tuna with a crap ton of cilantro.  
Creamy roll is also good ... but I try not to order it since it's deep fried :/  The roll has scallops and spicy tuna, but then it's breaded fried and served with a creamy wasabi sauce.
Overall, the rolls here are mediocre.  They'll satisfy my sushi craving, but they're not amazeballs.

The combo dishes or hot dishes can be good, but they're not really all that impressive either.   The sizzling hot plate scallops were flavorful, but could be texturally disturbing for those who don't enjoy the gelatinous consistency achieved from cornstarch.  Udon broth could use some serious work.  

Despite needing a little work in some areas, the snake roll, creamy roll, and Tuesday deals keep me coming back!
author: Dina H.

description:
A good friend of mine lives only a block away from this place, and we always find ourselves ordering for pick up at this place. It's an 'atleast once a week' type of place. 

Favorites:

Salmon sashimi
Tuna/Salmon/Himachi nigri
Cherry Blossom roll
Spicy Tuna roll
Christmas roll

We usually choose about 4 of those things and it comes to ~$35-40. Might be a tad bit pricier than other sushi places I've been to, but this place sure is quality. I prefer a better tasting sushi place for a few bucks more versus a mediocre sushi place for cheap. This place has quality covered. 

I've never actually eaten inside the restaurant, but it looks like a cozy spot for a date. The place is pretty small, and probably fills up fast around dinner time.
author: Ashley D.

description: I feel bad to give it a one star but I was hungry and I still threw most of it away. The fish tasted old. I ordered sushi, two different rolls and the salmon teriyaki. As a point of comparion, I much more prefer Live Sushi and Naked Fish.
author: Heather R.

description:
The service was good and for being just around the corner from my apartment, you can't beat the location, but sadly you can beat the sushi. I expected a lot more for the price in SF. It wasn't that the fish was bad, it was just lacking in flavor and with so many different places just down the street that have awesome sushi for the same price or cheaper, I'm not sure why you would choose this place. The saving grace was the creamy roll, but being lightly fried it wouldn't be enough to make me come back. 

Overall, not bad, but there are so many other great places in SF for sushi...
author: Emily S.

description: nothing too special here!! I might come again for happy hours on Tuesday~~ good service though. Food is just okay~~
author: Penny L.

description: This place is TINY but a step up from Sushi Rock down the hill.  Being an LA Japanese food snob, it's hard to get comfortable with what's available in SF for Japanese, but Sushi Rapture makes a good effort.  It's right next door to one of my best friends, so we've been here a few times to catch up for dinner.  We both get the Teishoku Combo, which, like Sushi Rock, allows you to taste a number of items without a full fledged commitment.  My Teishoku box usually consists of Chicken Teriyaki, Chicken Karaage, and Tempura.  Much like Sushi Rock, I avoid the fish here, just in case.  It's nothing personal, I've only eaten sashimi at Zushi Puzzle here and that's only because I know everything there is fresh.  For $13 though, this isn't a terrible option, just be prepared for mediocrity.
author: Lisa I.

description: Sushi Rapture is my favorite Nob Hill neighborhood sushi place.  Very fresh sushi and friendly staff.  I love the sashimi combo.  My one gripe is that they don't take American Express and complain about credit cards for under $15.  Parking is a huge pain though, so good thing they deliver.
author: Greg B.

description:
I went for sushi and wished they had a large menu for rolls.  When we came it was a rainy day middle of the week right before supper time maybe 4 or 5? We were the only customers. There were two girls working. One behind the sushi counter, and one was sitting at the sushi bar on her computer doing work. 

They sat us at a table, and we had to ask the person sitting down what we wanted because there really wasn't a server coming to check on us or ask us what we would of liked to order. Also, the two girls went in back together whenever they were going to make our food. I felt it was very confusing, who was the chef? Was there even a server? 

I remember they did have a great deal on happy hour sake, so we had that. I also liked their oysters, which was also a happy hour deal. Their salmon handrolls were good as well.

I guess all in all it was okay, if I was rating it for customer service, well it sucked, but for food it was alright.
author: Katrina M.

description:
I live a few blocks from this place and it is my go-to happy hour spot, especially on Tuesdays when it's buy 1 sake get one free! My favorite thing to order from their HH menu are the $2 salmon hand rolls, miso soup and edamame. I also love all of their sushi, but the hand rolls are such a good deal. 

I usually come here with a group of friends and we drink too much sake and have a fantastic time. The people who work at Sushi Rapture are the greatest too. They treat everyone like friends, especially if you become a regular. If you happen to be there when they close the restaurant on the weekend, they usually open ginormous bottles of sake and just start pouring shots. Little sushi place turned party!
author: Theresa H.

description: Average sushi and below average service. I suspect it only stays in business because of its convenient location.
author: Brian R.

description:
After walking 5 blocks uphill in boots, I can safely say I enjoyed this place. We arrived around 730pm and there was only 1 table that was occupied. I love that because I was tired and hungry and wanted to be seated ASAP. It's a small space and is tastefully decorated. Any parties larger than 4 would have to have some sort of reservations. The service is great here. Very attentive and efficient. 

The sushi is pretty good but their specials are what you should definitely try. Their fish is fresh and the portions are just right. The rice covered sushi rolls were kind of thick. The rice was sticky as well. Otherwise, I have no complaints and would definitely come here again.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: I always have a good experience here, and the beek tataki is just...Yum. Miso soup + beef tataki + chocolate mochi = happy me.
author: Grace F.

description: We came during their happy hour and ordered the special with spicy tuna, salmons skin, salmon, crab and white tuna hand rolls for $2 each, rainbow roll and seaweed salad. The food was good, not spectacular, nor was it bad. We didn't get any sashimi so it was kind of hard to tell if they used great fish or not.
author: Alice W.

description:
Great find! We were visiting San Fran for the first time, and upon recommendation from our hotel concierge as to where he (as a local) goes to eat sushi, we visited Sushi Rapture. 

Very quiet place and friendly service. The sushi rolls were massive! My husband also ordered some sashimi, and was very impressed with both the portion size and quality.  They also had a great selection of fish on special which we would have never been able to get back home.

Worth stopping in if you're in the area and looking for some good sushi!
author: Anna B.

description: Sushi Rapture is a tiny little neighborhood sushi joint that serves the Nob Hill area. I stopped by with a friend who is a regular visitor on a weekday for a late lunch. Their 2 item lunch bento box is an awesome deal at just $7.95! I got the chicken katsu and the tempura, which came with not just ONE but TWO tempura battered fried shrimp. The other tempura veggie pieces left a lot to be desired, though. I have never before encountered fried seaweed pieces, but they do it here! I also got a sweet potato or carrot (didn't eat it, couldn't tell what it was under that fried stuff), and a broccoli. The chicken katsu was extremely heavily breaded, so much so that it was slimy in the middle next to the chicken. They gave a very generous portion though and it had a nice crunch to it. It also came with miso soup (average), rice (nicely cooked), salad (strangely filled with cabbage and clumpy dressing), two pieces of fried gyoza (okay), and a slice of orange (good palate cleanser). But for $7.95, I thought this was a damn good deal. And it was filling to boot! I'd consider returning to try out their rolls. The sushi chef will make something up on the spot for you if you tell him what you like and don't like and feel like eating at that moment.
author: Leslie H.

description: Really fresh fish and friendly staff. Also great happy hour!
author: Ashley W.

description:
Finding parking and having dinner at this Russian/Nob Hill Sushi corner-spot can be a hassle for outsiders, who don't live in the neighborhood. But for us, it is crawling distance from our crib. 

Matt convinced wife into eating Japanese for a change. Whenever we go out, all she wants is her own ethnic food. Well, Matt changed all that tonight. 

We started out with Gyoza Potsticker as our opening appetizer. The $5.00 Japanese Pot-sticker was flaming hot and tasty with the Japanese hot-sauce.

Our main entree, Matt had the Beef-Teriyaki dinner plate and she had the Chicken Katsu. Both our $10.00 meals came with Japanese Rice, Salad, Miso-Soup and an endless cup of soothing Green-Tea. The Beef-Teriyaki was very tender and the sauce wasn't too salty and the Chicken Katsu was battered very well and tasted crispy. 

We also split an order of Maki Roll. The $5.00 sushi plate came with four pieces comprised of Cucumber, Nori, Shitake Mushrooms and rice. It was not a bad choice. 

Whenever Matt's job permits him from getting a day-off, he does whatever he can to enjoy a pleasant dinner close-by from his crib.
author: Matt G.

description:
Hm, not bad not bad... 

I came here for someone's birthday because the Greek place down the street was booked for someone ELSE's birthday already. Turns out, in a way we got our own private party because Sushi Rapture is a tiny little place - our 8 person party took up half the seating in the restaurant (the other half was empty). Walking into an empty restaurant on a Friday night in the city is quite scary...

On the up side, we were able to get in and out of there in an hour. The Yellowtail Sashimi was given in generous portions, was moderately fresh, but had a strong fishy taste yuck. I'd recommend asking the Chef for fresh sushi of the day. My favorite is the combination dinner because I am absolutely the MOST indecisive person ever. Thety allow you to choose THREE of 10 entrees for your dinner, and even narrowing that down was tough. Kinda sucks that you have to pay $1 extra for short ribs or salmon, but it still came out to $15 pre-tax/tip. (chicken + short ribs + salmon, miso soup, side salad, rice). By the way the salmon isn't worth it, DO NOT GET IT. 

Not too shabby for a Friday night.
author: Jess C.

description: I had the sashimi combo.  Service was good and the restaurant was clean.  The Butterfish and the Salmon sashimi were winners the rest (Tuna, Hamachi) had a bit of fishy aftertaste.  I am rating this place 4 stars because the prices are very good in comparison to other sushi bars.
author: Teck L.

description:
My experiences at Sushi Rapture have been anything but rapturous (two stars is me being generous). Antonyms for rapture are much more apt in describing this place - disappointment, discontent and dissatisfaction. My first visit was on a Tuesday in the early evening. I was struck by how much the place felt like a noisy sports bar with both the patrons and the guy behind the sushi counter using booming voices to express their thoughts and feelings regarding the game being shown on the flat screen TV. The sushi was decent on that trip but I was so annoyed with everything about the visit that I held off on writing my review in order to give the place another chance. I really wanted this restaurant to be good as I love sushi and other Japanese food and it's just blocks from my house.

I gave Sushi Rapture a second chance this afternoon. Once again the guy behind the sushi counter was yelling at other patrons (this time regarding his love for the A's). I ordered the lunch special choosing chicken karaage and beef teriyaki. The chicken karaage was doughy and limp --- with none of the usual crispiness. The beef teriyaki was only slightly better though very fatty. My companion described the California roll as "not great" and felt the rice was dry. The best thing about our lunch was the green tea. 

If you're looking for a "Cheers"-like atmosphere, don't mind shelling out for mediocre food and prefer to eat with lots of yelling and commotion going on around you --- Sushi Rapture is a winning choice.

I, however, will be seeking out a new sushi spot in the 'hood.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Was very excited to order sushi delivery; was a little bummed when what they said my price was upon delivery was more than I'd expected after calculating it out from their posted prices.

The roll I ordered was fantastic and innovative; the chef's choice sashimi was decent but un-exciting; ditto for the chef's choice sushi.  Came with a tiny amount of rice for the amount of food I'd ordered.

So, I liked it, mostly because it delivered, but wasn't uber excited.
author: Tasha D.

description: Took over an hour to deliver and I line only 2 blocks away.  Don't bother
author: Kay D.

description:
This is my go-to for sushi delivery near Polk Street. 

The 3 piece combo (Teishoku) is the best deal on the menu. For $13 you get miso soup, rice, a small green salad and three small sides. I always go for the tuna and sake sashimi as well as the cal roll. Add an edamame for $3 and you are full. Nom nom.

I suggest ordering quite a bit before you are starving. They usually quote 45 min. to an hour, and every time I have ordered that is about right on the money. Also closed on Mondays!!
author: Natalie N.

description:
Ordered three rolls at 5pm Sunday evening and was told it would be a 45 minute wait. ! I was surprised they were either so busy at this time or not staffed up for deliveries to locations a hop skip away. It took 55 minutes, incidentally.

We ordered three rolls that knocked us back $36. The creamy roll was delicious but a bit too oily (the whole roll is tempura) and not enough scallops inside to make me want to order it again. Rice: fish ratio was too high on that one. The sauce it comes definitely left an impression on my nose though. Yowza!
author: Kim K.

description:
Hands down my favorite sushi place in the City.  The place is always hopping and there can be a wait to get a table (it's very small, maybe 5 tables and the sushi bar) but it is SO worth the wait.  The spider rainbow rolls and the Raider rolls are my favorite.  Sam and Andrea always recognize the regulars, and treat every customer as if they were a regular.  The fish is fresh, and now that I have moved away from SF I only WISH there were someplace around here where you could get sushi half as good.  

Only downside is little to no street parking.  Luckily, most of the time that I went here I was dating a guy who lived a block away so parking wasn't an issue - but the 27 bus from the Powell St station drops you off right in front of there, too.  Or, you could take a cable car as they run past it as well.
author: Katie S.

description: I ordered from here maybe twice, mostly because I live up the street and the service is friendly, but I'll never go back after my last trip. I went a couple of weeks ago with my boyfriend, my sister, and her boyfriend. We walked in and the place REEKED of fish. We thought about leaving, but we were all starving so we agreed that it wasn't worth the trouble to find another place. We all split rolls, except for my boyfriend who got nigiri, and ended up with HORRIBLE food poisoning the next day. We knew it was food poisoning because his parents are doctors and were able to diagnose him. Sorry for the bad review, because the folks are really nice, but felt that this needed to be shared.
author: Anna H.

description:
I've kinda sorta started to come here almost every weekend. I've gotten into this strange habit of cooking all the other days (I'm a broke ass student), so you know it's both special and convenient for me to slide into a pair of jeans and cuddle up with a bowl of udon and of course, my beloved creamy roll. Anyway, like all good relationships, you have to tell the restaurant that you adore that you love them, that you would do anything for them, that there is no one above them (they are on a pretty steep hill you know).

So, Sushi Rap, we're 5 creamy rolls away from a sweet engagement. Once I roll in the dough being a human rights activist (ha), I'll buy you a ring.
author: Natasha P.

description:
My (S)Nob Hill- dwelling sister and her roomie both love this place,but I don't see the appeal except for its proximity to their apartment.  We ordered the following:

-Spicy Scallop Maki.  Good, but I've had better.  Too much mayo, as is the problem with scallop rolls almost everywhere I go.  
-49er Roll.  You couldn't possibly go wrong my three fave sushi ingredients: salmon, scallops, and lemon.  Me likey.  
-Dynamite Maki.  Holy *bleep* (and not in a good way)...well, at least I was warned this yellowtail roll would be spicy.  But what's with the sprouts?  

Honestly, it's not bad sushi...it's just that I've had mall sushi in LA that was better.  Sorry!
author: Nancy C.

description: This place is my 2nd home. Great people and great fish. Sammy and the rest of the staff are always friendly and provide great service.
author: John L.

description: We ordered a couple of rolls and an order of ramen. The rolls were pretty forgetful and the ramen was pretty bland. The server was nice though.
author: chris s.

description:
Great little place! My friend and I were just walking through the neighborhood when we saw this place and decided to get some sushi. We were very pleasantly surprised. The sushi was extremely fresh! In fact it almost melted in your mouth. I ordered the Cal Rock, which was some of the best crab/eel sushi I have ever tried and that is saying a lot because I am borderline obsessed with crab sushi. My friend was also very happy with her order. Needles to say, we are both definitely coming back for more. 

The only downfall for this place is the lack of parking in the Nob Hill area which makes it very hard to get to. Otherwise, I would definitely recommend this place to others.
author: Kate G.

description: Their sushi is good, it's served within a reasonable amount of time, plus it's in a convenient location for me. However, the service can be spotty in my experience. I've come here a few times in the past few months, and my experiences with their service have included nobody greeting me - the sushi chefs looking at me when I walked in the door, saying nothing, then continuing to work, only to heartily greet the group who entered about 5 seconds after me. They also tried handing me my takeout order without a bag to carry my food in.
author: Storm T.

description: Amazing food, fantastic service, great neighborhood sushi. Don't forget to ask about the Lyndsey roll:-0
author: Nick C.

description:
I came here on a Tuesday night, where they have Happy Hour specials from 5pm to 7pm, as well as $1 oysters throughout the day. 

I tried the $1 oysters as well as a selection from the Happy Hour list: sake, Sapporo (bottle), hand rolls (salmon, white tuna), and miso soup. Most everything on the Happy Hour list was $2; the miso soup was $1. 

There is a buy a large sake, get one free offer, but I found the $2 sake special to be plenty (enough for two people to share). 

The oysters could have been fresher. The miso soup and hand rolls tasted standard, but the prices were excellent. I also had agedashi tofu, which came in small cubes, allowing them to absorb more broth/flavor. 

I finished with the tempura ice cream. The menu does not indicate that it is made with green tea ice cream. The ice cream was good, but the ratio of tempura batter to ice cream was about 1:1 -- it would taste better with more ice cream. 

I will definitely return on Tuesdays.
author: Zelda Z.

description: Not very impressed. Service was sub-par - they forgot to bring us miso soup, and we had to ask for water. One roll came out quickly but we had to ask them to check on the rest of the order because it was taking so long. The creamy roll was really good (deep fried which I was not expecting, would have been nice to have a better description) and the 49ers roll was also good, the rest were very generic. The rolls were very pricey for how ordinary they were. It wasn't a terrible experience, but there are a ton of sushi places in SF so the bar is set pretty high.
author: Amy G.

description:
For delivery only:

I have ordered from Sushi Rapture off of Seamless a couple of times and the outcome is always the same: it arrives over an hour after I order, even though the advertised delivery time is 30-45 minutes. When I call, the excuse is always the same: they received a bunch of orders all at the same time and sorry, but tonight is really hectic.

If you want sushi in a timely fashion, avoid.
author: M U.

description:
This place. I've never had a restaurant go from a place I really liked the two first times I went there, and the third time was such utter garage. I thought about giving it another star, just because I'd enjoyed the first two times. But no.

The waitress was a complete idiot. Not paying attention, messing up order, ignoring us... the whole nine yards of bad service. And we were the only people in the small restaurant. 10 minutes later another couple came. 

The food was so bad, we had to eat something later just to get the taste of the horrible sushi out of the mouth. We ate gum but our souls just felt full of bad sushi.
author: Anish B.

description:
All this downpour is putting a damper to our beloved hobby of eating out!!!  Fortunately, we live in a city with many delivery options.  Otherwise, we might just starve to death :-)  For lunch today, we were both hankering for sushi (as we often do) so I looked to GrubHub.com for help and, voila! found this place!   

After we finished placing the order, the man said it'll be 25 mins.  After we hung up, we looked at each other in disbelief since we're about 15 mins. away by car even in the best road condition at the projected speediness (he was on speakerphone) and said, "Did he say 25 mins.?!"  Well, 30 mins. later, our food arrived, much to our delight (we forgave the 5 mins. tardiness :-))

We ordered the following: Gyoza, Oshitashi, Salmon sashimi, combination sashimi and 49er roll.  The items that stood out for us are: the combination sashimi, a rather generous order with 5 different types of very fresh-tasting fish and the Salmon sashimi, a skimpy portion of thinly cut fish.  The rest were just fine, we were happy.  But what made us the happiest was the quick delivery time!/  Please don't ever change!!
author: Yvette F.

description:
1.  The service was terrible ( until it was time for the bill and tip, then she  finally smiled and acted like she cared). 
2. Was not very fresh or good. 
3. Raw egg can only goes so well with certain things, you cant just put it on anything and expect not to gag just a teeny weeny little bit. 
4. Forgot our orders and didnt bring us what we exactly ordered. 
5. $90 for bad sushi lunch makes me sad
author: Tasha A.

description:
I got delivery through GrubHub.

Best delivery sushi ever! The ratio of fish : rice was great, and the fish was fresh (you know, it tastes like a fresh ocean wave, rather than a bland fishy chunk of protein). I think my age tofu was intentionally cooked soupy and not fried so that I'd be able to enjoy it delivered -- it was yum.

Minimum order of $25 and generally pricier than other sushi places, but so yummy. I will probably order from here again.

~a
author: Ayumi Y.

description:
Awesome local tiny sushi spot. The combo stuff here is a deal.
